text: [Music]
hi everyone
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
boris album w this is a brand new lp
from japanese rock outfit boris they're
27th at this point i believe but it is
their first for sacred bones records who
say this project is directly connected
to the last major album the band
released that was 2020's no which
dropped in the thick of the pandemic and
featured the band raging through all of
these chaotic and cathartic fusions of
thrash metal and sludge metal some fans
may remember that lp fittingly ended
with a ambient interlude which i guess
bridges over into the first track to
this new lp i want to go to the side
where you can touch which is a light
airy guitar drone packed with all these
ethereal reverbed out tones very cold a
little eerie and progressively building
up to these somewhat shrill whooshing
sounds that bring the whole thing to a
sudden close now conceptually this is so
boris link two records together and
sequalize them one of your most
aggressive and hard-hitting records and
one of your most maybe ambient and
easygoing because boris isn't just one
of the most significant bands out there
in doom and stoner metal they have some
classics in the drone metal category as
well so a record with more ambient
leanings isn't exactly outside of the
band's wheelhouse in so many ways w is
set up to be a w but digging into it it
is actually a surprisingly meager
offering sadly this thing didn't really
follow through with a cohesive vision
and sound in the way that most boris
albums do and the angles it does seem to
be most consistently working don't
really hold a candle to any of the
band's high points so far for one many
of the drone passages on this thing run
pretty thin there's very little weight
or depth to them sonically what layers
are there inhabit similar frequency
ranges and also are awash in similar
effects so
they usually bleed together into a kind
of
dull and mildly grating wall of sound
one of the only tracks that stood out in
this direction was maybe old projector
which is mostly due to the supremely
cavernous lead guitar phrasings that are
all bent up
by some whammy bar work and ultimately
this thing ends up sounding like a dream
sequence and some kind of noir surf film
which even if this thing doesn't have
like the greatest progression in the
world is a strangely evocative image now
there's another side to w as well where
the band is pulling together these very
minimal very faint kind of dodgy and
indirect layers of bass and guitar drums
and vocals which are very abstract and
very impressionist rarely is anything in
terms of a melodic idea being
communicated all that clearly if this is
an attempt at like some ambient strain
of art pop i don't think it's being done
all that well tracks like icelena and
drowning by numbers are so soft and so
gentle to the ear but simultaneously
come off really disheveled and sort of
unpleasant and not really in an eerie or
scary or unsettling a menacing way i
guess the unpleasantness comes more from
a lack of instrumental cohesion and
guiding vision for the song i was
actually pretty enamored with the sound
of drowning by numbers when i first
heard it but the more i listened to it
in the context of this record the more i
felt like the atmosphere it embodied
just wasn't enough the composition the
song the instrumentation at the core of
it was just too messy and just slapped
together you will know is really the
best of the bunch when it comes to these
uh ambient fusions but even this track
kind of loses steam fast as it doesn't
really hold up for the nine minutes that
it lasts maybe the best and most
gripping tracks on this lp are the ones
that sound like uh they're the most out
of place be it the fallen which is just
loaded with all these crushing doomy
riffs very distorted very loud uh the
the volume level here and compares with
everything else is just night and day
and then there's also beyond good and
evil which i think has a solid very easy
going start and eventually builds up
into this really huge heavy climactic
post-rock-esque finish and honestly in
my opinion is the most gratifying track
on this lp from front to back but yeah
sadly i found this boris record to be a
very weak one there's nothing really all
that concrete or memorable about it
stunning or impressive about
the songwriting the song play the
production and i'm not really seeing
what is
guiding pretty much the mediocrity of
this project other than i i guess
potentially for it to be
such a harsh contrast from their last
full-length album i'm feeling a decent
two strong four on this one tran
position have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
is another video that you can check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano boris w
uh forever
